titleStmt.title: Please cite this article in press as: X. Peng, Y. Yang, Algorithms for interval-valued fuzzy soft sets in stochastic multicriteria decision making based on regret theory and prospect theory with combined weight

analytic.title: Please cite this article in press as: X. Peng, Y. Yang, Algorithms for interval-valued fuzzy soft sets in stochastic multicriteria decision making based on regret theory and prospect theory with combined weight

biblStruct.note: Received 10 October 2015 Received in revised form 8 April 2016 Accepted 24 June 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Interval-valued fuzzy soft set Distance measure Combined weight Regret theory Prospect theory

div.p: This paper presents two novel interval-valued fuzzy soft set approaches. First, we initiate a new axiomatic definition of interval-valued fuzzy distance measure, which is expressed by interval-valued fuzzy number (IVFN) that will reduce the information loss and remain more original information. Then, the objective weights of various parameters are determined via normal distribution. Combining objective weights with subjective weights, we present the combined weights, which can reflect both the subjective considerations of the decision maker and the objective information. Later, we propose two algorithms to solve stochastic multi-criteria decision making problem, which take regret aversion and prospect preference of decision makers into consideration in the decision process. Finally, the effectiveness and feasibility of two approaches are demonstrated by two numerical examples.

div.head: Q3
div.p: Many complex issues in environmental science, engineering, medical science, and economics involve vagueness and fuzziness. While a wide variety of existing theories such as probability theory, fuzzy set theory [1], rough set theory [2], and interval mathematics [3] have been developed to model incertitude. However, each of these theories has its inherent difficulties as pointed out in [4]. The soft set theory, initiated by Molodtsov [4], is free from the inadequacy of the parameterized tools of those theories [1][2][3].

Current works on soft set are developing rapidly. The study of hybrid models combing soft sets with other mathematical structures is an important research topic. Maji et al. [5] firstly explored fuzzy soft sets, a more generalized notion combining fuzzy sets and soft sets. Yang et al. [6] developed the concept of interval-valued fuzzy soft sets. Peng et al. [7] presented Pythagorean fuzzy soft sets, and discussed their operations. Yang et al. [8] proposed the multi-fuzzy soft sets and successfully applied them to decision making, meanwhile they extended the multi-fuzzy soft sets to that of bipolar multi-fuzzy soft sets [9] which can describe the parameter more accurately and precisely. Wang et al. [10] initiated the hesitant fuzzy soft sets by integrating hesitant fuzzy set [11] with soft set model, and presented an algorithm to solve decision making problems. Xiao et al. [12] presented trapezoidal fuzzy soft set. Feng et al. [13] established a colorful connection between rough sets and soft sets. Jun [14,15] studied the application of soft sets in BCK/BCI-algebras and initiated soft BCK/BCI-algebras. Aktas ¸ and C ¸ agman [16] gave a definition of soft groups, and derived their basic properties using Molodtsov's definition of the soft sets. Yamak et al. [17] proposed soft hyperstructure and studied some properties of soft subhypergroupoids. C ¸ agman et al. [18] defined the soft topology on a soft set, and presented its related properties. Moreover, there have been some applications of interval-valued fuzzy soft sets such as parameter reduction [19], clustering analysis [20], decision making [21,22].

The above decision models and methods are mainly based on the assumptions of full rationality. However, in practical decision making, people do not behave in a completely rational manner, and the obvious deviations between the actual decision making behavior and predictable values of the expected utility theory will be appeared. In 1947, Simon [23] proposed the principle of "bounded rationality", and he thought that human beings only had a bounded rationality for the decision making. Kahneman and Tversky [24] collected many individual behavior researches by investigations and experiments on the basis of Simon's "bounded rationality", and initiated the prospect X. Peng, Y. Yang / Applied Soft Computing xxx (2016) xxx-xxx theory. To be clear, the decision maker always overvalues the small probability event and ignores the normal event, and he is more sensitive to losses than gains. Therefore, the decision making based on prospect theory is more in accordance with real decision making behavior and it has become a research topic recently [25][26][27][28].

Regret theory, initiated by Bell [29] and Loomes and Sugden [30], is one of the most popular nonexpected utility models. The core idea is that the decision makers not only pay attention to the results obtained by the choice of the alternative, but also pay attention to the outcome of other alternatives, and avoid choosing the alternative that will make them regret [29,30]. Moreover, there have been some applications of regret theory such as investment choices [31,32], route choice [33], auctions [34], decision making [35].

Stochastic multi-criteria decision making (SMCDM) is one of the most important styles of multi-criteria decision making (MCDM), which is characterized by the existence of multiple natural states in the decision making and cannot determine what states will appear, but can be estimated in advance of each the probability of the occurrence of the natural state, and the parameter values of alternative are different in different natural states. So stochastic multi-criteria decision making has a wide range of practical background. To the best of our knowledge, however, the study of the interval-valued fuzzy soft SMCDM problems based on regret theory and prospect theory has not been reported in the existing academic literature.

In order to compute the distance of two interval-valued fuzzy sets, we propose a new axiomatic definition and distance measure, which takes in the form of interval-valued fuzzy set. Comparing with the existing literature [36][37][38][39], our distance measure can remain more original decision information.

Considering that different sets of criteria weights will influence the ranking results of alternatives, we develop a novel method to determine the criteria weights by combining the subjective factors with the objective ones. This model is different from the existing methods, which can be divided into two categories: one is the subjective weighting methods and the other is the objective weighting methods, which can be computed by normal distribution [40]. The subjective weighting methods pay much attention to the preference information of the decision maker [22,41], while they neglect the objective information. The objective weighting methods do not take into account the preference of the decision maker, in particular, these methods fail to take into account the risk attitude of the decision maker [21,42,43]. The characteristic of our weighting model can reflect both the subjective considerations of the decision maker and the objective information. Consequently, combining subjective weights with objective weights, we provide a combined model to determine criteria weights.

To facilitate our discussion, we first review some background on soft sets, interval-valued fuzzy sets, interval-valued fuzzy soft sets, regret theory and prospect theory in Section 2. In Section 3, we introduce a new interval-valued fuzzy distance, which takes in the form of interval-valued fuzzy set. In Section 4, two approaches to interval-valued fuzzy soft sets in SMCDM based on regret theory and prospect theory are designed. In Section 5, two examples are presented to verify the proposed methods. Finally, conclusions are pointed out in Section 6.

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: In this section, we will briefly recall the basic concepts of soft sets, fuzzy soft sets, interval-valued fuzzy soft sets, regret theory and prospect theory. See especially [4][5][6]24,29,30] for further details and background.

2.1. Basic concepts of soft sets, fuzzy soft sets, interval-valued fuzzy sets and interval-valued fuzzy soft sets Definition 2.1. ([4]) Let P(U) be the set of all subsets of U. A pair ( F, A) is called a soft set over U, where F is a mapping given by F : A → P(U).

div.head: Definition 2.2. ([5]
div.p: ) Let P(U) be the set of all fuzzy subsets of U. A pair ( F, A) is called a fuzzy soft set over U, where F is a mapping given by F : A → P(U).

div.head: Definition 2.3. ([44]
div.p: ) An interval-valued fuzzy set (IVFS) I in U is given by
where
div.formula: 0 ≤ I -(x) ≤ I + (x) ≤ 1. For simplicity, we call i = [I -(x), I + (x)] an interval-valued fuzzy number (IVFN) denoted by i = [i -, i + ]. Definition 2.4. ([45]) Let x = [x -,
div.p: x + ] and y = [y -, y + ] be two IVFNs, ∈ [0, 1], then their operational laws are defined as follows:

From (1), we can see that it may be not satisfied the definition of IVFN when x = [0.3, 0.4], y = [0.7, 0.8], but it has significance of computation. Meanwhile, for (7), we know that it is out of positive number range, but it also has significance of computation. We can see IVFN as a special interval number which can be satisfied the above condition.

div.head: Definition 2.5. ([6]
div.p: ) A pair (F, A) is called an interval-valued fuzzy soft set over U, where F is a mapping given by F : A → P(U). P(U) denotes the set of all interval-valued fuzzy subsets of U.

Let x ∈ U and e ∈ A. F(e) is an interval-valued fuzzy subset of U, and it is called an interval-valued fuzzy value set of parameter e. Let F(e)(x) denote the membership value that object x holds parameter e, then F(e) can be written as an interval-valued fuzzy set that Then, (F, A) is described by the following Table 1.
Definition 2.7. ([6,20]) The complement of an interval-valued fuzzy soft set (F, A), is denoted by (F, A) c and is defined by (F, A) c = (F c , A).
Based on above definition, Peng and Yang [20] defined a distance measure between F(e) and G(e) in the following
Inspired by Xu [46], we give a comparative law based on interval-valued fuzzy soft sets by score function and deviation function.
Definition 2.8. Let (F, A) be an interval-valued fuzzy soft set, then the score function of (F, A) is defined as follows:
div.formula: S((F, A)) = m i=1 n j=1 F -(e j )(x i ) + F + (e j )(x i ) -1 2mn .(3)
div.p: Definition 2.9. Let (F, A) be an interval-valued fuzzy soft set, then the deviation function of (F, A) is defined as follows:
In the following, we only take m = n = 1 into consideration for computing the distance of two IVFNs.
Based on above score function and deviation function, we derive the following comparative law.
Definition 2.10. For two interval-value fuzzy soft sets (F, A) and (G, A), then
div.formula: (1) if S((F, A)) > S((G, A)), then (F, A) is superior to (G, A), denoted by (F, A) (G, A); (2) if S((F, A)) < S((G, A)), then (G, A) is superior to (F, A), denoted by (F, A) ≺ (G, A); (3) if S((F, A)) = S((G, A)), then (a) if D((F, A)) > D((G, A)), then (G, A) is superior to (F, A), denoted by (F, A) ≺ (G, A); (b) if D((F, A)) = D((G, A)), then (G, A) is equivalent to (F, A), denoted by (F, A) ∼ (G, A); (c) if D((F, A)) < D((G, A)), then (F, A) is superior to (G, A), denoted by (F, A) (G, A).

div.head: Basic concepts of regret theory
div.p: Regret theory, initially proposed by Bell [29] and Loomes and Sugden [30], is a new important reasoning method, and does not require preferences to be transitive. It is a nontransitive model representing preferences by a bivariate utility function, which takes the feelings of regret and rejoice into consideration. It can account for many phenomena which expected utility theory fails to explain, such as Allais paradox [47], Ellsberg paradox [48], preference reversal [49].
In the following, we will introduce some concepts of utility function.
Definition 2.11. ( [29]) Let x denote the variable of attribute value, then the utility function v(x) of benefit attribute is defined as follows:

where ˛ is risk aversion coefficient of decision maker. And the greater the ˛, the greater the degree of risk aversion of decision maker. The effect of ˛ on the utility function v(x) of benefit attribute is shown in Fig. 1.

Please cite this article in press as: X. It is easily known that utility function v(x) of benefit attribute is a monotonically increasing concave function, and satisfies v (x) > 0 and v (x) < 0. Definition 2.12. ( [33]) Let x denote the variable of attribute value, then the utility function v(x) of cost attribute is defined as follows:

where ˇ is risk aversion coefficient of decision maker. And the greater the ˇ, the greater the degree of risk aversion of decision maker. The effect of ˇ on the utility function v(x) of cost attribute is shown in Fig. 2.

It is easily known that utility function v(x) of cost attribute is a monotonically decreasing concave function, and satisfies v (x) < 0 and v (x) < 0. Definition 2.13. ( [35]) Let X = [X -, X + ] be an attribute value, then the utility value of X can be defined as follows:
div.formula: V = X + X - v(x)f (x)dx,(7)
div.p: where f(x) is the probability density function. In this paper, for f(x), we take the form of normal distribution. When x obeys normal distribution N( , 2 ), according to the 3 principle [50] in the knowledge of probability and statistics, x is covered by a probability of 99.73% in interval [X -, X + ], i.e., = (X -+ X + )/2, = (X + -X -)/6. The probability density of x is defined as follows:
Definition 2.14. ([29]) The regret-rejoice function R( v) can be defined as follows:

Please cite this article in press as: X. where is risk aversion coefficient of decision maker. And the greater the , the greater the degree of risk aversion of decision maker. v = v 1 -v 2 denotes the difference in the utility value of 2 alternatives. When
div.formula: R( v) > 0, R( v) denotes rejoice value. When R( v) < 0, R( v)
div.p: denotes regret value. Based on Eq. ( 9), for some difference v 0 of two alternatives, |R(-v 0 )| > |R( v 0 )| comes into existence with the increase of . It represents that the decision maker of psychological perception for -v 0 is more sensitive than v 0 . Fig. 3 visualises the effect of on the regret-rejoice function R( v).

div.head: Basic concepts of prospect theory
div.p: Prospect theory, initially proposed by Kahneman and Tversky [24], assumes that the decision maker will select the optimal alternative according to the prospect values of all alternatives, which is co-determined by the value function and the probability weight function, i.e.,
div.formula: V = n i=1 w(p i ) ( x i ), (10
div.p: where V is the prospect value, ( x i ) is the value function which reflect by the decision makers' subjective feelings. x i = x ix 0 represents the positive or negative deviation degree between the existing wealth and decision maker psychological balance point, where x 0 is the decision reference point, i.e., psychological balance point of the decision maker. When the existing wealth exceeds the reference point, we can define the outcome as the gain; otherwise, we define the outcome as the loss. w(p i ) is the probability weight function. The prospect theory emphasizes the difference between expectation and result, rather than the result itself, so the choice of reference point is very important.
The value function proposed by Tversky and Kahneman [51] has the following form:

where x represents the gain or loss, and the gain is positive and the loss is negative; ˛ and ˇ represent the concavo-convex degree of the power function in the area of the gain and loss, respectively, 0 < ˛ < 1 and 0 < ˇ < 1 show sensitivity decrement; the values of ˛ and ˇ are larger, and the decision maker is more prone to risk; Â represents the steeper characteristics in the loss region than in the gain region, and Â > 1 shows that the attitude of decision maker is the loss aversion. Obviously, v(0) = 0. After experimental verification, for the parameters ˛, ˇ and Â in Eq. ( 11), Kahneman and Tversky [24] gave ˛ = ˇ = 0.88 and Â = 2.25. The value function ( x) is shown in Fig. 4.
The probability weight function proposed by Tversky and Kahneman [51] is shown as follows:

where and ı are the risk gain attitude coefficient and risk loss attitude coefficient, respectively. After experimental verification, Kahneman and Tversky [24] gave = 0.61, ı = 0.72. When p is much smaller,w(p) > p, it denotes that the decision maker overestimates small probability event. When p is much larger, w(p) < p, it denotes that the decision maker ignores the normal event. The probability weight function w(p) is shown in Fig. 5.

div.head: A new interval
div.formula: D (I i , I k ) = [1 -max{L(I i , I k ), H(I i , I k )}, 1 -min{L(I i , I k ), H(I i , I k )}],(13)
div.p: where
div.formula: L(I i , I k ) = n j=1 w j min{i - ij ,i - kj } n j=1 w j max{i - ij ,i - kj } , H(A i , A k ) = n j=1 w j min{i + ij ,i + kj } n j=1 w j max{i + ij ,i + kj }
div.p: , and w j is the weight of jth IVFN.
Proof. In order for D (I i , I k ) to be qualified as a sensible distance measure for IVFSs, it must satisfy the (1)-( 4) of axiomatic requirements.
It is easy to verify the (1)-( 3). So we only prove (4). (
div.formula: ) If I 1 ⊆ I 2 ⊆ I 3 , then i - 1j ≤ i - 2j ≤ i - 3j and i + 1j ≤ i + 2j ≤ i + 3j .4
div.p: Hence, L(I
div.formula: 1 , I 3 ) = n j=1 w j min{i - 1j ,i - 3j } n j=1 w j max{i - 1j ,i - 3j } = n j=1 w j i - 1j n j=1 w j i - 3j ≤ n j=1 w j i - 1j n j=1 w j i - 2j = n j=1 w j min{i - 1j ,i - 2j } n j=1 w j max{i - 1j ,i - 2j } = L(I 1 , I 2 ), H(I 1 , I 3 ) = n j=1 w j min{i + 1j ,i + 3j } n j=1 w j max{i + 1j ,i + 3j } = n j=1 w j i + 1j n j=1 w j i + 3j ≤ n j=1 w j i + 1j n j=1 w j i + 2j = n j=1 w j min{i + 1j ,i + 2j } n j=1 w j max{i + 1j ,i + 2j } = H(I 1 , I 2 ). Furthermore, 1 -max{L(I 1 , I 2 ), H(I 1 , I 2 )} ≤ 1 -max{L(I 1 , I 3 ), H(I 1 , I 3 )}, 1 -min{L(I 1 , I 2 ), H(I 1 , I 2 )} ≤ 1 -min{L(I 1 , I 3 ), H(I 1 , I 3 )}. Consequently, D (I 1 , I 2 ) ⊆ D (I 1 , I 3 ).
div.p: Similarly, D (I 2 , I 3 ) ⊆ D (I 1 , I 3 ). This completes the proof. Especially, for any two IVFNs i 1 and i 2 , the distance measure between
is defined as follows:
div.formula: D (i 1 , i 2 ) = 1 -max min{i - 1 , i - 2 } max{i - 1 , i - 2 } , min{i + 1 , i + 2 } max{i + 1 , i + 2 } , 1 -min min{i - 1 , i - 2 } max{i - 1 , i - 2 } , min{i + 1 , i + 2 } max{i + 1 , i + 2 } . (14

div.p: the distance is the largest.

div.head: Approaches to interval-valued fuzzy soft sets in SMCDM based on regret theory and prospect theory
Problem description
div.p: For an interval-valued fuzzy soft SMCDM problem, let X = {x 1 , x 2 , . . ., x m } be a set of alternatives, A = {e 1 , e 2 , . . ., e n } a set of parameters and W = {w 1 , w 2 , . . ., w n } a set of parameter weights. Denoted by S = {S 1 , S 2 , . . ., S l } the possible status and p t the probability of the status S t such that 0 ≤ p t ≤ 1 and l t=1 p t = 1. Given l interval-valued fuzzy soft sets (F t , A)(t = 1, 2, . . ., l). Assume that the evaluation of the alternative x i with respect to the parameter e j in status S t is represented by F t (e j )(x i ). Then the interval-valued fuzzy soft SMCDM matrix can be shown as Table 2.

div.head: The method of computing the combined weights
div.p: The normal distribution is one of the most commonly observed and is the starting point for modeling many natural processes. It is usually found in events that are the aggregation of many smaller, but independent random events. Inspired by Xu [40], we propose a new method to compute objective weights.

div.head: Computing the objective weights: normal distribution method
div.p: Definition 4.1. Let F t (e j )(x i )(i = 1, 2, . . ., m ; t = 1, 2, . . ., l ; j = 1, 2, . . ., n) be a collection of IVFNs, the average of F t (e j )(x i ) is computed as follows:
div.formula: t j = m i=1 F - t (e j )(x i ) m , m i=1 F + t (e j )(x i ) m . (15
div.p: Definition 4.2. Let F t (e j )(x i )(i = 1, 2, . . ., m ; t = 1, 2, . . ., l ; j = 1, 2, . . ., n) be a collection of IVFNs, and t j is the arithmetic mean of these IVFNs, then we define the standard deviation as follows:
div.formula: t j = 1 m m i=1 d(F t (e j )(x i ), t j ) 2 ,(16)
div.p: where d(F t (e j )(x i ), t j ) can be computed by Eq. ( 2).
Based on Definitions 4.1 and 4.2, we can determine each alternative with respect to parameter of objective weight w t ij as follows:
div.formula: w t ij = 1 √ 2 t j e - (d(F t (e j )(x i ), t j )) 2 2( t j ) 2 . (17
div.p: Please cite this article in press as: X. Later, we can obtain each parameter of objective weight w t j (j = 1, 2, . . ., n)
div.formula: w t j = m i=1 w t ij = m i=1 1 √ 2 t j e - (d(F t (e j )(x i ), t j )) 2 2( t j ) 2 . (18
div.p: By normalizing w t j (j = 1, 2, . . ., n), we make their sum into a unit, and get as follows:
div.formula: ω t j = w t j n j=1 w t j = m i=1 1 √ 2 t j e - (d(F t (e j )(x i ), t j )) 2 2( t j ) 2 n j=1 m i=1 1 √ 2 t j e - (d(F t (e j )(x i ), t j )) 2 2( t j ) 2 . (19
div.p: where
div.formula: l t=1 w t j p t l
div.p: is the average weight of objective weights in different status, n j=1 j = 1, 0 ≤ j ≤ 1. We aggregate the objective weight and subjective weight by non-linear weighted comprehensive method. The larger the value of the objective weight and subjective weight are, the larger the combined weight is, or vice versa, based on the multiplier effect. Meanwhile, we can know that Eq. ( 20) overcomes the limitation of only considering either subjective or objective factor influence. The advantage of Eq. ( 20) is that the criteria weights and rankings of alternatives can reflect both the subjective considerations of decision maker and the objective information.

div.head: A novel interval-valued fuzzy soft set approach in SMCDM based on regret theory
div.p: Based on regret theory and combined weight model, we propose the stochastic multi-criteria decision making approach as follows: Algorithm 1.
Step 1. Construct an interval-valued fuzzy soft stochastic multi-criteria decision making matrix T = (F t (e j )(x i )) l×n×m , which is shown in Table 2.
Step 2. Compute the utilize value V t ij (i = 1, 2, . . ., m; j = 1, 2, . . ., n; t = 1, 2, . . ., l) of F t (e j )(x i )(i = 1, 2, . . ., m ; j = 1, 2, . . ., n ; t = 1, 2, . . ., l) by Eq. ( 21).
dx, e j is benefit parameter,
div.formula: F + t (e j )(x i ) F - t (e j )(x i ) 1 -e ˇx ˇ1 √ 2 t ij e - (x -t ij ) 2 2( t ij ) 2 dx, e j is cost parameter, (21
div.p: where
div.formula: t ij = F - t (e j )(x i )+F + t (e j )(x i ) 2 , t ij = F + t (e j )(x i )-F - t (e j )(x i ) 6 .
div.p: Step 3. Derive the alternative x i related to x k with respect to the parameter e j in status S t of regret value R t ikj and rejoice value G t ikj by Eqs. ( 22) and ( 23), respectively.
div.formula: R t ikj = 1 -e -(V t ij -V t kj ) , V t ij < V t kj , 0, V t ij ≥ V t kj .(22)
G t ikj = 0, V t ij < V t kj , 1 -e -(V t ij -V t kj ) , V t ij ≥ V t kj .(23)
div.p: Please cite this article in press as: X. It is obvious that R t ikj ≤ 0, G t ikj ≥ 0 and R t iij = G t iij = 0. Step 4. Calculate the alternative x i related to x k with respect to the parameter e j of regret value R ikj and rejoice value G ikj by Eqs. ( 24) and (25), and construct each parameter of the two alternatives' comparison of regret value matrix R j = [R ikj ] m×m and rejoice value matrix
div.formula: G j = [G ikj ] m×m , respectively. R ikj = l t=1 p t R t ikj ,(24)
G ikj = l t=1 p t G t ikj . (25
div.p: Step 5. Normalize the 26) and ( 27), respectively,
div.formula: R j = [R ikj ] m×m and G j = [G ikj ] m×m in R j = [R ikj ] m×m and G j = [G ikj ] m×m by Eqs. (
R ikj = R ikj RG + j ,(26)
G ikj = G ikj RG + j ,(27)
div.p: where
div.formula: RG + j = max{ max i,k=1,2,...,m {|R ikj |}, max i,k=1,2,...,m {G ikj }}, R ikj ∈ [-1, 0], G ikj ∈ [0, 1].
div.p: Step 6. Determine the combined weights j (j = 1, 2, . . ., n) by Eq. ( 20).

Step 7. Obtain the alternative x i related to x k of regret value R ik and rejoice value G ik by Eqs. ( 28) and ( 29), and construct the two alternatives' comparison of comprehensive regret value matrix R = [R ik ] m×m and comprehensive rejoice value matrix G = [G ik ] m×m , respectively.
div.formula: R ik = n j=1 j R ikj ,(28)
G ik = n j=1 j G ikj . (29
div.p: Step 8. Compute the alternative x i related to all other alternatives of overall regret value by Eq. (30).
div.formula: R i = m k=1 R ik ,(30)
div.p: where R i can be considered as a decision maker to the overall psychological perception of the alternative x i inferior to all other alternatives and R i ≤ 0. The greater the R i , the lower the level of the alternative x i for other alternatives. Step 9. Compute the alternative x i related to all other alternatives of overall rejoice value by Eq. (31).
div.formula: G i = m k=1 G ik ,(31)
div.p: where G i can be considered as a decision maker to the overall psychological perception of the alternative x i superior to all other alternatives and G i ≥ 0. The greater the G i , the higher the level of the alternative x i for other alternatives.
Step 10. Calculate the sort value of alternative x i by Eq. ( 32), based on PROMETHEE II method [52].
div.formula: i = R i + G i . (32
div.p: Step 11. Rank the order of alternatives by Eq. (32). The larger the value of i (i = 1, 2, . . ., m) is, the better the alternative is.

div.head: A novel interval-valued fuzzy soft set approach in SMCDM based on prospect theory
div.p: Based on prospect theory and combined weight model, we propose the stochastic multi-criteria decision making approach as follows: Algorithm 2.
Step 1. Construct an interval-valued fuzzy soft stochastic multi-criteria decision making matrix T = (F t (e j )(x i )) l×n×m , which is shown in Table 2.
Please cite this article in press as: X. Step 2. Transform the matrix T = (F t (e j )(x i )) l×n×m into the normalized T = (F t (e j )(x i )) l×n×m by Eq. (33).
div.formula: F t (e j )(x i ) = [F - t (e j )(x i ), F + t (e j )(x i )], e j is benefit parameter, [1 -F + t (e j )(x i ), 1 -F - t (e j )(x i )], e j is cost parameter. (33
div.p: Step 3. Set a preference point x 0 = [0.5, 0.5], compare the x 0 with F t (e j )(x i ) by Eq. ( 3) and compute the distance D t (F t (e j )(x i ), x 0 ), then calculate the prospect value V ij by Eq. (34).
div.formula: V ij = l t=1 w(p t ) (F t (e j )(x i ) -x 0 ), (34
div.p: where
Step 4. Determine the combined weights j (j = 1, 2, . . ., n) by Eq. ( 20),
Step 5. Compute the integrated prospect value V i of alternative x i by Eq. (37).
div.formula: V i = n j=1 j V ij .(37)
div.p: Step 6. Compute the score function of V i (i = 1, 2, . . ., m). The larger the value of S(V i ) is, the better the alternative is.

div.head: Two illustrative examples
div.p: This section considers two investment decision making problems. We give the following examples to illustrate our approaches.

Example 5.1. ( [41]) Assume that an internet company wants to invest money in the best possible option. There is a panel of four possible alternatives to invest: e-commerce development project, game development project, browser development project, and web development project. The company selects three parameters to evaluate the four software development projects. Let U = {x 1 , x 2 , x 3 , x 4 } is the set of software development projects under consideration, A = {e 1 , e 2 , e 3 } is the set of parameters, e 1 stands for economic feasibility, e 2 stands for technological feasibility, e 3 stands for staff feasibility. In the three parameters, e 1 and e 2 are benefit parameters, and e 3 is cost parameter.

And the decision values take form of IVFNs, assuming that the decision values are in the range of the normal distribution. According to the market forecast, we assume that there are three natural statuses S = {S 1 , S 2 , S 3 } for parameters: high risk (S 1 ), medium risk (S 2 ) and low risk (S 3 ), and the corresponding probability of each status p = {p 1 , p 2 , p 3 } are 0.1, 0.5 and 0.4, respectively. Suppose that the decision maker has the following prior weight set given by his/her prior experience or preference: = ( 1 , 2 , 3 ) = (0.4, 0.2, 0.4). The assessments for alternatives arising from questionnaire investigation to the expert are presented in Table 3.
The concrete calculation steps are listed as follows:
Algorithm 1.
Step 1. Construct an interval-valued fuzzy soft stochastic multi-criteria decision making matrix as shown in Table 3.

Step 2. The utilize value V t ij (i = 1, 2, 3, 4; j = 1, 2, 3; t = 1, 2, 3) of F t (e j )(x i )(i = 1, 2, 3, 4 ; j = 1, 2, 3 ; t = 1, 2, 3) can be computed by Eq. ( 21) (˛ = ˇ = 0.02, = 0.1). And utilize value matrix is shown as Table 4.

By means of the Algorithms 1 and 2, we can find that the final results are the same, i.e., x 4 is the most desirable investment alternative. Hence, the two approaches proposed above are effective and feasible.

div.p: Our work is sponsored by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (61163036). We thank the anonymous referees for their valuable comments and constructive suggestions which greatly improved the quality of this paper.

Step 4. Determine the combined weights j (j = 1, 2, . . ., n) by Eq. ( 20), 1 = 0.1749, 2 = 0.3565, 3 = 0.4686. Step 5. Compute the integrated prospect value V i of alternative x i by Eq. ( 37),

By means of the Algorithms 1 and 2, we can find that the final results are the same, i.e., x 1 is the most desirable investment alternative. Hence, the two approaches proposed above are effective and feasible.
In the following, we give some comparisons of Algorithms 1 and 2.
(1) Comparison of applied situation When the decision maker takes regret aversion into consideration in the decision process, the Algorithm 1 is given priority to make decision.
When the decision maker takes prospect preference into consideration in the decision process, the Algorithm 2 is given priority to make decision.
(2) Comparison of computational complexity

We know that Algorithm 1 will be consumed more computational complexity than Algorithm 2, especially in step 2. So if we take the computational complexity into consideration, the Algorithm 2 is given priority to make decision.

div.head: 3) Comparison of discrimination
div.p: Comparing the results in Algorithm 1 with Algorithm 2, we can find that the results of Algorithm 2 are quite close and vary from -0.796017 to -0.587619 or -0.856926 to -0.581095. These result of decision values cannot clearly distinguish, in other words, the results derived from Algorithm 2 are not very convincing (or at least not applicable). On the contrary, the Algorithm 1 has a clearly distinguish. So if we take the discrimination into consideration, the Algorithm 1 is given priority to make decision.

div.head: Conclusion and remarks
div.p: The major contributions in this paper can be summarized as follows:

(1) We construct a new axiomatic definition of interval-valued fuzzy distance measure and give a distance formula. Comparing with the existing literature [36][37][38][39], it can reduce the information miss and remain more original information. (2) A novel interval-valued fuzzy soft approach in stochastic multi-criteria decision making based on regret theory is explored, which has not been reported in the existing literature. The approach pays attention to the outcome of other alternatives, and avoids choosing the alternative that will make them regret. (3) A novel interval-valued fuzzy soft approach in stochastic multi-criteria decision making by score function based on prospect theory, which emphasizes the difference between expectation and result, rather than the result itself. (4) The subjective weighting methods pay much attention to the preference information of the decision maker [22,31], while they neglect the objective information. The objective weighting methods do not take into account the preference of the decision maker, in particular, these methods fail to take into account the risk attitude of the decision maker [21,32,33]. The characteristic of our weighting model can reflect both the subjective considerations of the decision maker and the objective information.
In the future, we shall apply more advanced theories into interval-valued fuzzy soft set and solve more decision making problems.
